ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Vandervoort's Dairy recognizes the facility's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Vandervoort's Dairy is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at Vandervoort's Dairy. 



It is Vandervoort's Dairy's policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable plant personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare plant personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.



The Vandervoort's Dairy facility draws from decades of internal experience and expertise, as well as resources of The Kroger Company to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.



One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  The Regulatory Compliance Manager is responsible for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.



In addition to the P

lant Safety Program, the Vandervoort's Dairy facility follows the following corporate and site-specific safety guidelines:



- Employee Handbook Plant Safety Rules

- Kroger Company Contractor Safety Rules

- Kroger Company Total Quality Initiative (TQI) process

- Kroger Company Manufacturing Safety Key Element Assessment (KEA) & Management

- Kroger Company Behavioral Accident Prevention Process (BAPP) Steering Committee

- General Office (GO) Safety Inspection program and abatement plans





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Vandervoort's Dairy began operation in the 1930s and has been supplying Texas with milk, ice cream, and butter since!  The facility in Fort Worth is part of the Kroger Company.  It is a dairy manufacturing plant that produces fluid milk and cultured products, yogurt, and juices.  An ammonia refrigeration system is used to enable the manufacturing and cold storage of food products.



The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the system is in excess of the regulatory threshold limit of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum inventory in the system is approximately 27,000 pounds.  Since an ammonia release from the system could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119), the system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's Risk Management Program.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The risk management policies and prevention programs consist of the following elements:



Employee Participation:  This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing the program.  Employees are also involved when a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have complete access to the PSM and RMP policies and procedures.



Process Safety Information:  Written information has been collected which enables the employees to iden

tify and understand the potential hazards in the system.  The written information includes the ammonia Safety Data Sheet and a detailed description of the design features of the ammonia refrigeration system, including the mechanical system of vessel, equipment, and piping, as well as the auxiliary systems such as the ammonia leak detection system, ventilation system, pressure relief design, etc.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  Formal PHA studies have been conducted to examine the system and identify potential hazards.  Recommendations are made by PHA Teams to improve facility safety and to mitigate deficiencies that are identified.  The recent PHA Studies utilized a three-tier approach (What-If, Industry Checklists, and Facility Site Inspection) to ensure a comprehensive evaluation of hazards was conducted.



Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps that should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.  These operating procedures include safety and health hazards, appropriate personal protective equipment, detailed steps for operating each ammonia refrigeration component, etc.



Training:  A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process.  Initial and refresher training is provided to all employees who are assigned responsibilities associated with the ammonia system.



Contractors:  All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.



Pre-Startup Safety Review:  A pre-startup safety review is conducted for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed

according to design standards before the project is commissioned.  A pre-startup safety review is also performed when the process safety information related to the system requires significant updates.



Mechanical Integrity:  This preventative maintenance program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration system and components are built and maintained appropriately.  Manufacturer's maintenance recommendations, industry standards, and company operating history were referenced in the development of the tasks and frequencies that comprise the maintenance program.



Hot Work Permit:  These procedures ensure that a signed Hot Work Permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning that is planned to be conducted on or near ammonia equipment and/or piping.



Management of Change:  Procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the design of the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed and managed.  Updates are made as needed to the various elements of the facility's PSM/RMP programs such as Process Safety Information, Mechanical Integrity, and Operating Procedures to ensure all elements remain current.



Incident Investigation:  The procedures to investigate incidents are formalized and require documentation by facility personnel including details of the cause(s) of the ammonia incident / near miss, identification of corrective actions to be taken to prevent similar future occurrences, all of which are backed up by the details of the event.  Recommendations for improvements are tracked to resolution.



Compliance Audits:  There are procedures to conduct Compliance Audits of the PSM/RMP prevention program elements to ensure that the program is in place and functioning properly.  Any recommendations from audits are resolved by facility personnel, which results in safety and compliance improvements.





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and

involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the Vandervoort's Dairy's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (May 9, 2019), there had been no ammonia releases within the previous that met the above criteria within the previous five years.



However, a release of 475 pounds of ammonia occurred at the facility in June 2018 due to a malfunction of a pressure relief valve located outside.  No injuries (on-site or off-site) or property damage were known.  Since the ammonia was released from an outdoor location, the vapor dispersed into the atmosphere and did not have any adverse affects.  The proper notifications of outside agencies were made including written follow up reports to the LEPC (Tarrant County LEPC).





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



An emergency response program has been implemented at the Vandervoort's Dairy facility.  This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies, including evacuation plans.  This program has been coordinated with the Ft. Worth Fire Department.



The Emergency Response Program consists of the following elements:



- Organization Plan and Responsibilities

- Communications Procedures

- Detailed Action Plans

- First Aid Procedures

- Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures

- Evacuation Plans

- Description of Outside Assistance Available

- Site Re-Entry Procedures

- Training Programs and Drills

- Revision and Update Criteria





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Vandervoort's Dairy is committed to the safety of employees as well as neighboring resi

dents and businesses.  Continual evaluations of risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration process by in-house personnel as well as outside risk management professionals help to limit the possibility of unintended impacts from the ammonia system.



Items identified in studies such as the recent Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation will be implemented to further reduce the risks.  Vandervoort's Dairy also plans to improve safety as follows:

 

- Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.

- Attendance and participation of key personnel in industry groups such as RETA and IIAR ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.

- Conducting routine RMP and PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by refrigeration personnel, contractors, consultants, or the safety department are discussed and addressed.

- Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facility's efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
